titleStmt.title: Induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein aggregation operators and their application to multiple attribute decision making

affiliation.orgName: Chongqing University of Arts and Sciences
Chongqing University of Arts and Sciences

analytic.title: Induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein aggregation operators and their application to multiple attribute decision making

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, we investigate the multiple attribute decision making (MADM) problems with hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information. We first introduce some operations on hesitant fuzzy sets, such as Einstein sum, Einstein product, Einstein exponentiation, etc., and propose the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy sets. Then, we further develop some new Einstein aggregation operators with hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information, such as the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein weighted average (HIVFEWA) operator, hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein weighted geometric (HIVFEWG) operator, hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted average (HIVFEOWA) operator, hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (HIVFEOWG) operator, induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator and induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator. Then, we apply the induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator and induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator to deal with multiple attribute decision making under the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy environments. Finally, an illustrative example is given to verify the developed approach and to demonstrate its practicality and effectiveness. Keywords: Multiple attribute decision making (MADM), hesitant interval-valued fuzzy values, Einstein aggregation operators, induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator, induced hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Multiple attribute decision making (MADM) handles decision situations where a set of alternatives (usually discrete) has to be assessed against multiple attributes or criteria before a final choice is selected [8]. Due to ambiguity and incomplete information in many deci-sion problems, it is often difficult for a decision-maker (DM) to give his/her assessments on attribute values and weights in crisp values. Instead, it has become increasingly common that these assessments are provided as fuzzy numbers (FNs) or intuitionistic fuzzy numbers (IFNs), leading to a rapidly expanding body of literature on MADM under the fuzzy or intuitionistic fuzzy framework [5, 6, 10, 11, 18-24, 27-29, 35, 36, 38, 39]. Atanassov [1,2] introduced the concept of intuitionistic fuzzy set (IFS), which is a generalization of the concept of fuzzy set [40]. Each element in the IFs is expressed by an ordered pair, and each ordered pair is characterized by a membership degree and a non-membership degree. The sum of the membership degree and the non-membership degree of each ordered pair is less than or equal to 1. Furthermore, Torra and Narukawa [13] and Torra [12] proposed the hesitant fuzzy set which permits the membership having a set of possible values and discussed the relationship between hesitant fuzzy set and intuitionistic fuzzy set, and showed that the envelope of hesitant fuzzy set is an intuitionistic fuzzy set. Xia and Xu [26] gave an intensive study on hesitant fuzzy information aggregation techniques and their application in decision making. Xu et al. [34] developed several series of aggregation operators for hesitant fuzzy information with the aid of quasi-arithmetic means. Gu et al. [7] utilized the hesitant fuzzy weighted averaging (HFWA) operator to investigate the evaluation model for risk investment with hesitant fuzzy information. Wei et al. [25] proposed two hesitant fuzzy Choquet integral aggregation operators: hesitant fuzzy choquet ordered averaging (HFCOA) operator and hesitant fuzzy choquet ordered geometric (HFCOG) operator. Wei [17] developed some prioritized aggregation operators for aggregating hesitant fuzzy information, and then apply them to develop some models for hesitant fuzzy multiple attribute decision making (MADM) problems in which the attributes are in different priority level. Zhu et al. [41] explored the geometric Bonferroni mean (GBM) considering both the BM and the geometric mean (GM) under hesitant fuzzy environment. Xu and Xia [32] proposed a variety of distance measures for hesitant fuzzy sets, based on which the corresponding similarity measures can be obtained. Xu and Xia [33] defined the distance and correlation measures for hesitant fuzzy information and then discuss their properties in detail. Wang et al. [16] proposed the generalized hesitant fuzzy hybrid weighted distance (GHFHWD) measure, which is based on the generalized hesitant fuzzy weighted distance (GHFWD) measure. The GHFHWD measure generalizes both the GHFWD and GHFOWD measures, and reflects the importance degrees of both the given arguments and their ordered positions.

All the above operators are based on the algebraic operational laws of IFSs for carrying the combination process and are not consistent with the limiting case of ordinary fuzzy sets [3]. Einstein operations include Einstein product and Einstein sum, which are good alternatives to the algebraic product and algebraic sum, respectively. Wang and Liu [15] treated the intuitionistic fuzzy arithmetic aggregation operators with the help of Einstein operations. Wang and Liu [14] further developed some new geometric aggregation operators, such as the intuitionistic fuzzy Einstein weighted geometric operator and the intuitionistic fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric operator and studied some desirable properties of these operators, such as commutativity, idempotency and monotonicity, and gave some numerical examples to illustrate the developed aggregation operators.

In many practical situations, there usually exists incomplete and uncertain information, and the decision makers cannot easily express their judgments on the candidates with exact and crisp values. Therefore, the interval-valued fuzzy set is usually more adequate or sufficient to model real-life decision problems than real numbers. So, we present hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy set based on hesitant fuzzy set. Therefore, how to extend the Einstein operations to aggregate the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information is a meaningful work, which is also the focus of this paper. To do so, the remainder of this paper is set out as follows. In the next section, we introduce some basic concepts related to hesitant fuzzy variables and Einstein operations. In Section 3, we propose some basic concepts related to hesitant interval-valued fuzzy variables and some operational laws of hesitant interval-valued fuzzy variables. In Section 4 we have developed some hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein aggregation operators: hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein weighted average (HIVFEWA) operator, hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein weighted geometric (HIVFEWG) operator, hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted average (HIVFE-OWA) operator, hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (HIVFEOWG) operator, induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator and induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator and studied some desirable properties of the proposed operators. In Section 5, we have applied the induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator and induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator to develop some models for multiple attribute decision making (MADM) problems with hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy information. In Section 6, a practical example is given to verify the developed approach and to demonstrate its practicality and effectiveness. In Section 7, we conclude the paper and give some remarks.

div.head: Hesitant fuzzy set
div.p: Atanassov [1,2] extended the fuzzy set to the IFS, shown as follows.
Definition 1. Given a fixed set X = {x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n }, an intuitionistic fuzzy set (IFS) is defined as
div.formula: A = ( x i , t A (x i ), f A (x i ) |x i ∈ X )(1)
div.p: which assigns to each elements x i a membership degree t A (x i ) and a non-membership degree f A (x i ) under the condition 0
div.formula: ≤ t A (x i ) + f A (x i ) ≤ 1, for all x i ∈ X.
div.p: However, when giving the membership degree of an element, the difficulty of establishing the membership degree is not because we have a margin of error, or some possibility distribution on the possibility values, but because we have several possible values. For such cases, Torra [12] proposed another generation of FS. Definition 2. [12]. Given a fixed set X, then a hesitant fuzzy set (HFS) on X is in terms of a function that when applied to X returns a sunset of [0, 1].
To be easily understood, Xia and Xu [26] express the HFS by mathematical symbol:

where h E (x) is a set of some values in [0, 1], denoting the possible membership degree of the element x ∈ X to the set E. For convenience, Xia and Xu [26] call h = h E (x) a hesitant fuzzy element (HFE) and H the set of all HFEs. Definition 3. [26]. For a HFE h, s (h) = 1 #h γ∈h γ is called the score function of h, where #h is the number of the elements in h. For two HFEs h 1 and
div.formula: h 2 , if s (h 1 ) > s (h 2 ), then h 1 > h 2 ; if s (h 1 ) = s (h 2 ), then h 1 = h 2 .

div.head: Einstein operations
div.p: The set theoretical operators have had an important role since in the beginning of fuzzy set theory. All types of the particular operators were included in the general concepts of the t-norms and t-conorms, which satisfy the requirements of the conjunction and disjunction operators, respectively. There are various t-norms and t-conorms families can be used to perform the corresponding intersections and unions of IFSs. Einstein operations includes the Einstein product and Einstein sum, which are examples of t-norms and t-conorms, respectively. They are defined as follows [9]: Einstein product ⊗ ε is a t-norm and Einstein sum ⊕ ε is a t-conorm, where

div.head: Hesitant interval-valued fuzzy set (HIVFS)
div.p: In many practical situations, there usually exists incomplete and uncertain information, and the decision makers cannot easily express their judgments on the candidates with exact and crisp values. Therefore, the interval-valued fuzzy set is usually more adequate or sufficient to model real-life decision problems than real numbers. So, we shall introduce the hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy set based on hesitant fuzzy set. Definition 4. [4]. Let X be a fixed set, a hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy set (HIVFS) on X is in terms of a function that when applied to each x in X and returns a subset of interval values in [0, 1].
To be easily understood, we express the HIVFS by a mathematical symbol:
div.formula: E = < x, hE(x) > x ∈ X (4
div.p: where hE(x) is a set of some interval values in [0, 1], denoting the possible membership degrees of the element x ∈ X to the set E. For convenience, we call hE(x) = h = γ L , γ R a hesitant interval-valued fuzzy element (HIVFE) and H the set of all HIVFEs. Given three HIVFEs h = γ L , γ R , h1 = γ L 1 , γ R 1 and h2 = γ L 2 , γ R 2 and λ > 0, we define their operations as follows:
div.formula: hλ = ∪ γ∈ h γ L λ , γ R λ ; λ h = ∪ γ∈ h 1 -1 -γ L λ , 1 -1 -γ R λ ; h1 ⊕ h2 = ∪ γ1 ∈ h1 , γ2 ∈ h2 γ L 1 + γ L 2 -γ L 1 γ L 2 , γ R 1 + γ R 2 -γ R 1 γ R 2 ; h1 ⊗ h2 = ∪ γ1 ∈ h1 , γ2 ∈ h2 γ L 1 γ L 2 , γ R 1 γ R 2 .
div.p: In order to compare among the IVHFEs, we introduce the concept of interval fuzzy numbers. Definition 5. Let ã = a L , a R = x a L ≤ x ≤ a R , then ã is called an interval fuzzy number. If 0 ≤ a L ≤ a R , then ã is called a positive interval fuzzy number [31].
Consider any two positive interval fuzzy number ã = a L , a R and b = b L , b R λ ∈ [0, 1], we define their operational laws as follows [31]:
div.formula: (1) ã + b = a L , a R + b L , b R = [a L + b L , a R + b R ]; (2) λã = λa L , λa R ; (3) ãk = a L k , a R k ; (4) ã • b = [a L • b L , a R • b R ]; Definition 6. Let ã1 = a L 1 , a R 1 and ã2 = a L 2 , a R
div.p: 2 be two interval fuzzy number, and let len
div.formula: (ã 1 ) = a R 1 -a L 1 , len (ã 2 ) = a R 2 -a L 2 ,
div.p: then the degree of possibility of ã1 ≥ ã2 is defined as [31] p (ã 1 ≥ ã2 )
div.formula: = max 1 -max a R 2 -a L 1 len (ã 1 ) + len (ã 2 ) , 0 , 0(5)
div.p: Similarly, the degree of possibility of ã2 ≥ ã1 is defined as:
div.formula: p (ã 2 ≥ ã1 ) = max 1 -max a R 1 -a L 2 len (ã 1 ) + len (ã 2 ) , 0 , 0(6)
div.p: From Definition 6, we can easily get the following results:

We now suppose that there are n input arguments hi = γ L i , γ R i (i = 1, 2, . . . , n) having the forms of interval fuzzy numbers. To rank these arguments, we first compare each argument hi = γ L i , γ R i with all arguments hj = γ L j , γ R j (j = 1, 2, . . . , n) by using Equation (5)(6); that is:
div.formula: p γi ≥ γj = max 1 -max γ R j -γ L i len ( γi ) + len γj , 0 , 0(7)
div.p: For simplicity, we let p ij = p γi ≥ γj . Then we develop a complementary matrix as follows:
Summing all the elements in each line of matrix P, we have: So, we can utilize Equations (5-6) to compare two score functions and judge the magnitudes of two IVHFEs.

Induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy
div.p: Einstein aggregation operators

div.head: Induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator
div.p: Motivated by the operations on the HIVFEs, let a t-norm T be the Einstein product ⊗ ε and t-conorm S be the Einstein sum ⊕ ε , then the generalized intersection and union on two HIVFEs h1 and h2 become the Einstein product (denoted by h1 ⊗ ε h2 ) and Einstein sum (denoted by h1 ⊕ ε h2 ) of two HIVFEs h1 and h2 , respectively, as follows:
div.formula: h1 ⊕ ε h2 = ∪ γ1 ∈ h1 , γ2 ∈ h2 γ L 1 + γ L 2 1 + γ L 1 γ L 2 , γ R 1 + γ R 2 1 + γ R 1 γ R 2 ; h1 ⊗ ε h2 = ∪ γ1 ∈ h1 , γ2 ∈ h2 γ L 1 γ L 2 1 + (1 -γ L 1 )(1 -γ L 2 ) , γ R 1 γ R 2 1 + (1 -γ R 1 )(1 -γ R 2 ) ; λ. ε h = ∪ γ∈ h 1 + γ L λ -1 -γ L λ 1 + γ L λ + 1 -γ L λ , 1 + γ R λ -1 -γ R λ 1 + γ R λ + 1 -γ R λ , λ > 0; h∧ ε λ = ∪ γ∈ h 2 γ L λ (2 -γ L ) λ + γ L λ , 2 γ R λ (2 -γ R ) λ + γ R λ , λ > 0
div.p: In the following, we shall develop some hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein arithmetic Aggregation operator based on the operations of HIVFEs and Einstein sum. Definition 8. Let hj (j = 1, 2, . . . , n) be a collection of HIVFEs, then we define the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein weighted average (HIVFEWA) operator as follows:
div.formula: HIVFEWA h1 , h2 , . . . , hn = n ⊕ ε j=1 ω j hj (8)

div.formula: n j=1 ω j = 1.

In the following, we shall develop an induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator which is an extension of induced ordered weighted averaging (IOWA) operator proposed by Yager and Filev [37]. Definition 10. Let hj (j = 1, 2, . . . , n) be a collection of HIVFEs. An induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator of dimension n is a mapping I-HIVFEOWA: Hn → H, that has an associated vector w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T such that w j > 0 and
div.formula: n j=1 w j = 1. Furthermore, I-HIVFEOWA w u 1 , h1 , u 2 , h2 , . . . , u n , hn = n ⊕ ε j=1 w j hσ(j)(19)
div.p: where w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T is a weighting vector, such that w j > 0,

In the following, we shall develop an induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator which is an extension of induced ordered weighted geometric (IOWG) operator proposed by Xu and Da [30]. Definition 13. Let hj (j = 1, 2, . . . , n) be a collection of HIVFEs. An induced hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator of dimension n is a mapping I-HIVFEOWG: Hn → H, that has an associated vector w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T such that w j > 0 and
div.formula: n j=1 w j = 1. Furthermore, I-HIVFEOWG w u 1 , h1 , u 2 , h2 , . . . , u n , hn = n ⊗ ε j=1 hσ(j)
div.p: w j (32) where w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T is a weighting vector, such that w j > 0, n j=1 w j = 1, j = 1, 2, . . . , n, hσ(j) is the hi value of the HIVFEOWG pair u i , hi having the jth largest u i (u i ∈ [0, 1]), and u i in u i , hi is referred to as the order inducing variable and hi as the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy values.

Based on Einstein sum operations of the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy values described, we can drive the Theorem 23. Theorem 23. Let hj (j = 1, 2, . . . , n) be a collection of HIVFEs. An induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator of dimension n is a mapping I-HIVFEOWG: Hn → H, that has an associated vector w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T such that w j > 0 and
div.formula: n j=1 w j = 1. Furthermore, I-HIVFEOWG w u 1 , h1 , u 2 , h2 , . . . , u n , hn = n ⊗ ε j=1 hσ(j) w j = ∪ γσ(1) ∈ hσ(1) , γσ(2) ∈ hσ(2) ,..., γσ(n) ∈ hσ(n) ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ 2 n j=1 γ L σ(j) w j n j=1 2 -γ L σ(j) w j + n j=1 γ L σ(j) w j , 2 n j=1 γ R σ(j) w j n j=1 2 -γ R σ(j) w j + n j=1 γ R σ(j) w j ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ ⎫ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎬ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎭(33)
div.p: where w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T is a weighting vector, such that w j > 0, n j=1 w j = 1, j = 1, 2, . . . , n, hσ(j) is the hi value of the HIVFEOWG pair u i , hi having the jth largest u i (u i ∈ [0, 1]), and u i in u i , hi is referred to as the order inducing variable and hi as the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy values.
It can be easily proved that the I-HIVFEOWG operator has the following properties.

div.head: Theorem 24. (Commutativity). I-HIVFEOWG
div.formula: w u 1 , h1 , u 2 , h2 , . . . , u n , hn = I-HIVFEOWG w u 1 , h 1 , u 2 , h 2 , . . . , u n , h n where u 1 , h 1 , u 2 , h 2 , . . . , u n , h n is any per- mutation of u 1 , h1 , u 2 , h2 , . . . , u n , hn . div.head: An approach to multiple attribute decision making with hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information
div.p: In this section, we shall utilize the induced hesitant interval-valued Einstein aggregation operators to multiple attribute decision making with hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy information. The following assumptions or notations are used to represent the MADM problems for potential evaluation of emerging technology commercialization with hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information. Let A = {A 1 , A 2 , . . . , A m } be a discrete set of alternatives, and G = {G 1 , G 2 , . . . , G n } be the state of nature. If the decision makers provide several values for the alternative A i under the state of nature G j with anonymity, these values can be considered as a hesitant interval-valued fuzzy element hij . In the case where two decision makers provide the same value, then the value emerges only once in hij . Suppose that the decision matrix H = hij m×n is the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy decision matrix, where hij (i = 1, 2, . . . , m, j = 1, 2, . . . , n) are in the form of HIVFEs.

In the following, we apply the induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator and induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator to the MADM problems for potential evaluation of emerging technology commercialization with hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information.
Step 1. If we apply the I-HIVFEOWA and I-HIVFEOWG operators to decision making with intuitionistic fuzzy information, firstly, we determine the weight of I-HIVFEOWA and I-HIVFEOWG operators.

Step 2. Calculate the order-inducing variables u ij m×n to be used in the decision matrix for each alternative A i and the attribute G j . The experts use order-inducing variables to represent the complex attitudinal character involving the opinion of different members of the board of directors (Merigó, 2010).
Step 3. Utilize the decision information given in matrix R, and the I-HIVFEOWA operator ri = γ L i , γ R i = I-HIVFEOWA w ( u i1 , ri1 , u i2 , ri2 , . . . , u n , rin )
div.formula: = n ⊕ ε j=1 w j rσ(ij) = ∪ γσ(i1) ∈ hσ(i1) , γσ(i2) ∈ hσ(i2) ,..., γσ(in) ∈ hσ(in) ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ n j=1 1 + γ L σ(ij) w j - n j=1 1 -γ L σ(ij) w j n j=1 1 + γ L σ(ij) w j + n j=1 1 -γ L σ(ij) w j , n j=1 1 + γ R σ(ij) w j - n j=1 1 -γ R σ(ij) w j n j=1 1 + γ R σ(ij) w j + n j=1 1 -γ R σ(ij) w j ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ ⎫ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎬ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎭ i = 1, 2, . . . , m. (34

) Or ri = γ L i , γ R i = I-HIVFEOWG w ( u i1 , ri1 , u i2 , ri2 , . . . , u n , rin ) = n ⊗ ε j=1 rσ(ij) w j = ∪ γσ(i1) ∈ hσ(i1) , γσ(i2) ∈ hσ(i2) ,..., γσ(in) ∈ hσ(in) ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ 2 n j=1 γ L σ(ij) w j n j=1 2 -γ L σ(ij) w j + n j=1 γ L σ(ij) w j , 2 n j=1 γ R σ(ij) w j n j=1 2 -γ R σ(ij) w j + n j=1 γ R σ(ij) w j ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ ⎫ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎬ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎭ i = 1, 2, . . . , m. (35
div.p: to derive the overall preference values ri (i = 1, 2, . . . , m) of the alternative A i , where w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T is the associated vector of the I-HIVFEOWA and I-HIVFEOWG operators, such that w j > 0 and n j=1 w j = 1.
Step 4. Calculate the scores S hi (i = 1, 2, . . . , m) of the overall hesitant interval-valued fuzzy preference values hi (i = 1, 2, . . . , m).

Step 5. To rank these overall hesitant interval-valued fuzzy preference values S hi (i = 1, 2, . . . , m), we first compare each S hi with all the S hj (j = 1, 2, . . . , m) by using (4-5). For simplicity, we let p ij = p S hi ≥ S hj , then we develop a complementary matrix as P = p ij m×m , where
div.formula: p ij ≥ 0, p ij + p ji = 1, p ii = 0.5, i, j = 1, 2, . . . , m
div.p: Summing all the elements in each line of matrix P, we have
Then we rank the collective overall preference values S hi (i = 1, 2, . . . , m) in descending order in accordance with the values of p i (i = 1, 2, . . . , m).
Step 6. Rank all the alternatives A i (i = 1, 2, . . . , m) and select the best one(s) in accordance with S hi (i = 1, 2, . . . , m).
Step 7. End.

div.head: Numerical example
div.p: Thus, in this section we shall present a numerical example to show potential evaluation of emerging technology commercialization with hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information in order to illustrate the method proposed in this paper. There is a panel with five possible emerging technology enterprises A i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) to select. The experts selects four attribute to evaluate the five possible emerging technology enterprises: ① G 1 is the technical advancement; ② G 2 is the potential market and market risk; ③ G 3 is the industrialization infrastructure, human resources and financial conditions; ④ G 4 is the employment creation and the development of science and technology. In order to avoid influence each other, the decision makers are required to evaluate the five possible emerging technology enterprises A i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) under the above four attributes in anonymity and the decision matrix H = hij 5×4 is presented in Table 1, where hij (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, j = 1, 2, 3, 4) are in the form of HIVFEs.

In the following, we utilize the approach developed to show potential evaluation of emerging technology commercialization of five possible emerging technology enterprises with hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information.

Step 1. If we apply the I-HIVFEOWA and I-HIVFEOWG operators to decision making with hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information, we suppose that the weight of I-HIVFEOWA and I-HIVFEOWG operators is: w = (0.3, 0.1, 0.4, 0.2) T .

Step 2. The experts use order-inducing variables to represent the complex attitudinal character involving the opinion of different members of the board of directors (Merigó, 2010). The results are shown in Table 2.

Step 3. Utilize the decision information given in matrix R, and the I-HIVFEOWA and I-HIVFEOWG operators which has associated weighting vector w = (0.3, 0.1, 0.4, 0.2) T , we obtain the overall preference values rI of the alternatives A i (i = 1, 2, . . . , 5) which are shown in Tables 3,4.
Step 4. Calculate the scores s hi (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) of the overall hesitant interval-valued fuzzy preference values hi (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) which are shown in Table 5.

Step 5. Rank all the emerging technology enterprises A i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) in accordance with the scores s hi (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) of the overall hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy preference values by using (5)(6), the ordering of the alternatives are shown in Table 6. Note that >means "preferred to". As we can see, depending on the aggregation operators used, the ordering of the alternatives is the same and the best alternative is A 5 .

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, we investigate the multiple attribute decision making (MADM) problem based on the Einstein aggregation operators with hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy information. Then, motivated by the ideal of Einstein operation [9], we have developed some Einstein aggregation operators for aggregating hesitant interval-valued fuzzy information: hesitant intervalvalued fuzzy Einstein weighted average (HIVFEWA) operator, hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein weighted geometric (HIVFEWG) operator, hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted average (HIVFEOWA) operator, hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (HIVFE-OWG) operator, induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator and induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator. The prominent characteristic of these proposed operators are studied. Then, we have utilized induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted averaging (I-HIVFEOWA) operator and induced hesitant interval-valued fuzzy Einstein ordered weighted geometric (I-HIVFEOWG) operator to develop some approaches to solve the hesitant interval-valued fuzzy multiple attribute decision making problems. Finally, a practical example is given to verify the developed approach and to demonstrate its practicality and effectiveness.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: The author is very grateful to the editor and the anonymous referees for their insightful and constructive comments and suggestions, which have been very helpful in improving the paper. The work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant No. 61174149, Natural Science Foundation Project of CQ CSTC of the People's Republic of China (No. CSTC, 2011BA0035) and the Humanities and Social Sciences Foundation of Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China under Grant No.09XJA630010, No.11XJC630011.
